description: From Middle English alabastre, from Old French alabastre, from Latin alabaster (“box for perfume made of alabaster”), from Ancient Greek ἀλάβαστρος (alábastros), from earlier ἀλάβαστος (alábastos, “vase made of alabaster”). This may further derive from Egyptian ꜥj-r-bꜣstjt (“vessel of the Egyptian goddess Bast”). The Latin suffix -aster is unrelated, but may have influenced the spelling of the borrowing from Ancient Greek (whence a direct loan could have been rendered as *alabastrus).

examples: The crown is stored in an alabaster box with an onyx handle and a gold lock.
An ominous alabaster fog settled in the valley.

entries.meaning: A fine-grained white or lightly-tinted variety of gypsum, used ornamentally.
(historical) A variety of calcite, translucent and sometimes banded.
(color) An off-white colour, like that of alabaster.
